body: This PR is replaced by https://github.com/apache/cassandra/pull/3046, yes?

I suggest sending an email to the ML to find out what you mentioned to me offline: Are we ok merging this and surfacing a number of failures?

Thanks for the catch!

Yes, this can be merged to trunk, 5.1, 5.0.

> LGTM. The change doesn't incur performance penalty and should fix the correctness problem. Skipping a very tiny fraction of data is much smaller problem than inserting vastly incorrect data into histogram due to a race.

WRT performance. The results of `LatencyTrackingBench` have a lot of uncertainty, but if anything, they show a possible improvement in `update` throughput. It makes sense, as the number of volatile reads is reduced to 1 (using `decayLandmark` is no longer a volatile read)

closing as speaking with @belliottsmith turns out that the error I saw was a test issue... We are testing at the store level and the `CommandStores` level is where we update journal...

Closing as it looks like this was already handled in https://github.com/apache/cassandra/commit/1e2c88fff832d891b296165e9adda786182e850d.

A bit discouraging TBH against future contributions given that I opened this PR, nudged it multiple times when it was still a relevant PR, and then the work was ignored, so I'm left wondering "Why did I spend the time to try to contribute here?"

- Oh I posted the wrong link apologies. Amended now.
- `generate.sh -a` is unnecessary iiuc. It's noop. We're changing nothing there correct?
- `start` jobs get automatically deleted when you delete a job if a regexp matches.

`generate.sh -a is unnecessary iiuc. It's noop. We're changing nothing there correct?`
I tested yesterday that it is not noop. The deletion lines in the script trigger the removal of the correct repeated jobs from the default files which makes sense to me.
I pulled your branch, removed the `do not merge` commit and ran `./generate.sh -a`

``start` jobs get automatically deleted when you delete a job if a regexp matches.`
That is unclear and brittle. Why some jobs are removed by regex and some are deleted by us? What is this regex meant for originally? We should have either the regex deal with all the `start_` jobs or rely on our manual deletion. Otherwise it becomes prone to bugs and messy.

> I tested yesterday that it is not noop

Right you are! I tested on the wrong folder apologies. Good catch. I pushed with the regenerated files.

> That is unclear and brittle

Yes that's why getting the dev workflow hit regexp bugs we fixed together etc., it was a bit more involved, etc. But changing that implies a multi-branch _big_ change refactor unrelated to the problem here. I wouldn't like to block this ticket on that.

This pull request adds the ability to define the default table compression in the config.yaml file.

However, doing this led to an issue where System tables should not have the default table compression applied.  In order to support this the `TableParams.builder` needs to know the keyspace name when building so that it can be passed to the `CompressonParams.builder` where the filter for determining which tables get the old DEFAULT and which get the new calculated default Compression params is handled by the `CompressionParams.defaultParams(keyspace)` method.

This change in turn led to changes to several files where the keyspace name needed to be provided for the `TableParams.builder().build()` function call.

So I took a second look at your requested changes to the TransactionalMigrationFromMode, and didn’t add them since they don’t make sense in the context of accord <-> accord changes we talked about here: https://github.com/apache/cassandra/pull/3032/files#r1446421908
Without the assumption that a migration is always between paxos and accord, the comments don’t say much, so I just left them out. Let me know if you disagree and we can figure something out, I may be overlooking something
